content.title: Erythromelalgia (Erythermalgia)
content.definition: Rare vasomotor disorder characterized by episodes of burning pain, warmth, and erythema affecting the extremities (primarily feet), triggered by warmth or exercise, and relieved by cooling. The name derives from Greek erythros (red), melos (limb), and algos (pain).

key_concepts.description: Primary (idiopathic or inherited) vs Secondary (associated with myeloproliferative disorders, especially polycythemia vera and essential thrombocythemia, or other conditions)
Autosomal dominant mutations in SCN9A gene encoding Nav1.7 sodium channel; presents in childhood; lower pain threshold and increased sensitivity of nociceptive neurons
Myeloproliferative disorders (polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia) - most common; also SLE, RA, diabetes, multiple sclerosis, drugs (calcium channel blockers, bromocriptine)
Episodic burning pain, warmth, and redness of feet (rarely hands); symmetric; triggered by warmth, exercise, dependency; relieved by cooling (patients seek cold surfaces, fans, ice water)
Microvascular arteriovenous shunting causes decreased nutritive capillary flow despite increased total blood flow; tissue hypoxia triggers pain; warmth exacerbates shunting
Dramatic relief with aspirin is pathognomonic for erythromelalgia secondary to myeloproliferative disorders (platelet-mediated microvascular occlusion); primary forms do not respond to aspirin
CBC to rule out myeloproliferative disorder (thrombocytosis, polycythemia); consider JAK2 mutation testing; exclude secondary causes; skin biopsy rarely helpful
Avoid warmth; cooling measures (but avoid frostbite from excessive ice); aspirin for MPD-associated; gabapentin/pregabalin for primary; other options: tricyclics, SSRIs, sodium channel blockers
Chronic, often debilitating; may be refractory to treatment; secondary forms may improve with treatment of underlying disorder (cytoreduction for MPD)
Patients seeking relief may cause frostbite injury from excessive cooling; counsel on safe cooling practices

learning_objectives: Define erythromelalgia and distinguish from Raynaud phenomenon
Recognize the association with myeloproliferative disorders
Understand the diagnostic significance of aspirin response
clinical_pearls: Burning + red + warm + feet + relief with cooling = erythromelalgia
Opposite of Raynaud: warmth triggers rather than cold
Always check CBC for myeloproliferative disorder (PV, ET)
Inherited form: SCN9A mutation, childhood onset, no aspirin response
Warn patients about frostbite from excessive cooling
common_mistakes: Confusing with Raynaud (opposite triggers and colors)
Not trying aspirin trial for diagnostic/therapeutic purposes
Allowing patients to use dangerous cooling measures (frostbite)
